overall_summary: The reasoning trajectory demonstrates a practical approach to forecasting hourly transformer load (LUFL) by leveraging daily seasonality. With only 4 days of historical data, the analyst opts for a robust averaging method that captures the typical daily pattern, explicitly handling data constraints and output formatting requirements while acknowledging potential limitations like missing values.
common_data_patterns: Hourly fluctuations (low nighttime, morning peaks, daytime variations)
Handling of missing values (considered but not applied in this case)
key_insights: Dominant daily seasonality drives the forecasting approach
Limited historical data (4 days) favors simple methods over complex models like SARIMA/ETS
Averaging same-hour values across days smooths day-to-day variations
Explicit rounding of forecasts to match input data precision (3 decimal places)
Date sequence generation aligned with the 96-hour forecast horizon
complexity_analysis: Moderately complex: Combines data pattern recognition, method evaluation (SARIMA/ETS/naive), and practical implementation of averaging, with considerations for real-world constraints like missing values and output formatting.
